thread.title: WSW apologise to Arnie but drama rolls on
thread.title_full: WSW apologise to Arnie but drama rolls on

title: WSW apologise to Arnie but drama rolls on
text:
Wanderers apologise to Graham Arnold over banner incident but don’t call to tell him February 25, 2017 10:53am by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS WESTERN Sydney Wanderers apologised to Graham Arnold a week after a crude banner was displayed by their active supporters group during the Sydney Derby, but the Sydney FC manager wasn’t contacted directly by the club. 
After the Wanderers released a statement, Sky Blues CEO Tony Pignata tweeted that he had rung Arnold, who doesn’t have a social media account, and found out that no one from the club had called him to apologise. 
Pignata then tweeted that Wanderers CEO John Tsatsimas had attempted to call Arnold yesterday, but the call wasn’t answered. 
Football Federation Australia fined the Wanderers $20,000 for being found guilty of bringing the game into disrepute after members of the Red and Black Bloc displayed a tifo of the Sky Blues coach performing a sex act. It also saw 14 RBB members suspended by the club. Just spoke to Graham he hasn't heard from anyone at WSW. He isn't on social media. Just call him. Easy as that. https://t.co/eau1GhSgrG — Tony Pignata (@tpignata9) February 24, 2017 Spoke to @wswanderersfc CEO John Tsatsimas JT called Arnie late yesterday which wasn't answered JT and I go back a long way Time to move on https://t.co/cz5Zrq9Bwg — Tony Pignata (@tpignata9) February 24, 2017 
On Thursday, Tsatsimas ruled out a club apology to Arnold , but after the club finalised their review of the events that took place before Sydney’s 1-0 loss to Western Sydney, Wanderers Chairman Paul Lederer issued the below statement. 
“Unfortunately the events of the last week have overshadowed what we should be celebrating as a fantastic event between Sydney’s two A-League teams,” said Mr Lederer. Banner displayed by the RBB during the Sydney Derby. Source: Supplied 
“It is with great disappointment that the actions of a minority have prompted fairly stern action to be taken by the Club this week to eradicate anti-social behaviour. 
“On behalf of the Western Sydney Wanderers, we apologise to Graham Arnold and his family and to all others who have been offended by the abhorrent actions of a few who are now no longer part of our Club. 
“We urge everyone now to come together and celebrate the great event that the Sydney Derby has become and to attend future A-League matches in the right sporting spirit.” 
Tsatsimas told 2GB on Thursday: “We don’t apologise for the behaviour. 
“It wasn’t an official, it wasn’t conducted by a player ... 
“We [The Wanderers] won’t take responsibility for the poor actions of others.” 
Four days after the incident, Arnold said he would have liked an apology but never recieved one. 
“Apology? I would probably have liked one by now,” said Arnold. “I haven’t heard from them for four days so I don’t want one now. At the end of the day I would have hoped I would have got an apology, but I didn’t get one. That’s life and we just move on.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
